docs.abstract: Three days of debate at the Supreme Court prompt Brooks and Collins to discuss Justice Kennedy, the social contract, emergency rooms and the Constitution.
docs.snippet: Three days of debate at the Supreme Court prompt Brooks and Collins to discuss Justice Kennedy, the social contract, emergency rooms and the Constitution.

byline.original: By DAVID BROOKS and GAIL COLLINS

docs.lead_paragraph: He has more followers than most preachers, but unlike so many of them, Tim Tebow shows little interest in using his pulpit to take controversial stances.

headline.seo: Tebow Professes His Evangelical Faith Carefully

docs.abstract: New York Jets backup quarterback and professed evangelical Christian Tim Tebow has more followers than most preachers and politicians, but unlike so many of them, he shows little interest in using his pulpit to take controversial stances.
docs.snippet: He has more followers than most preachers, but unlike so many of them, Tim Tebow shows little interest in using his pulpit to take controversial stances.

byline.original: By JOHN BRANCH and MARY PILON

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who have a vaginal delivery after a Caesarean are at increased risk of bleeding; there is also a small risk of fetal or infant death compared with a second C-section.

headline.seo: Slight Risk in Vaginal Birth After C-Section
headline.main: Childbirth: Slight Risk in Vaginal Birth After C-Section
headline.print_headline: Childbirth: Slight Risk in Vaginal Birth After C-Section

docs.abstract: Dr Caroline A Crowther study published online in journal PLoS Medicine finds that women who choose to have a vaginal birth after a previous Caesarean section may be at a slightly increased risk of complications.
docs.snippet: Women who have a vaginal delivery after a Caesarean are at increased risk of bleeding; there is also a small risk of fetal or infant death compared with a second C-section.

docs.lead_paragraph: An investigation offers a sobering portrait of how Wyckoff Heights Medical Center has been undermined by the very people entrusted to run it.

headline.seo: At Ailing Wyckoff Hospital, Insider Deals and Lavish Perks
headline.main: At Ailing Brooklyn Hospital, Insider Deals and Lavish Perks
headline.print_headline: At Ailing Brooklyn Hospital, Insider Deals and Lavish Perks

docs.abstract: Three-month investigation into Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn offers a sobering portrait of how it, as a nonprofit hospital, has been undermined by the very people entrusted to run it; facility has been so troubled for so long that even the most accomplished leadership might have been unable to turn it around; but its recent difficulties, which are attracting the notice of the authorities, have clearly been deepened by management turmoil.
docs.snippet: An investigation offers a sobering portrait of how Wyckoff Heights Medical Center has been undermined by the very people entrusted to run it.

byline.contributor: Research was contributed by Jack Begg, Sheelagh McNeill, Lisa Schwartz, Jack Styczynski and Susan Weber-Stoger.Research was contributed by Jack Begg, Sheelagh McNeill, Lisa Schwartz, Jack Styczynski and Susan Weber-Stoger.

docs.lead_paragraph: The story of white poverty, as Carrie Buck’s story illustrates, is much longer and more complex than Charles Murray and his admirers realize or want to admit.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Nell Irvin Painter criticizes Charles Murray's book Coming Apart: The State of White America, 1960-2010; asserts book joins a long tradition of blaming the poor for their condition; observes that the story of white poverty is much longer and more complex than Murray and his admirers realize or want to admit.
docs.snippet: The story of white poverty, as Carrie Buck’s story illustrates, is much longer and more complex than Charles Murray and his admirers realize or want to admit.

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Five conservative male justices on the Supreme Court reached a decision divorced from reality when they ruled that self-care was not part of the Family and Medical Leave Act.

headline.seo: Sex Discrimination, Medical Leaves and the Supreme Court

docs.abstract: Editorial condemns Supreme Court ruling determining that states cannot be sued for not letting their workers take time off for their own serious medical problems; argues that the five conservative male justices reached a majority decision divorced from history and reality by ruling that self-care, a provision enacted in part to protect pregnant women from discrimination if they had medical reasons for taking time off, is not part of the Family and Medical Leave Act.
docs.snippet: Five conservative male justices on the Supreme Court reached a decision divorced from reality when they ruled that self-care was not part of the Family and Medical Leave Act.

headline.main: Read This, or Be the Worst Parent Ever

docs.abstract: Even the author of the parody "How Not to Kill Your Baby" fears he can't top the best comedy efforts of the good-parent book genre.
docs.snippet: Even the author of the parody "How Not to Kill Your Baby" fears he can't top the best comedy efforts of the good-parent book genre.
